In simple terms, the marginal effect refers to the additional benefit or value that an individual derives from consuming one more unit of a particular good or service. In other words, it's the extra satisfaction, pleasure, or benefit they get from consuming one more unit of that good or service, compared to the previous unit.

Here is a 5-sentence short story about "Finding the Way Home After Getting Lost":

One day, I went to the park with my friends to play. While we were exploring, I wandered too far from them and couldn't find my way back. I looked around, but all I saw were tall trees and unfamiliar faces. I began to feel scared and alone, wondering how I would find my way home. But then I remembered the landmark I had passed earlier, and I followed it back to the familiar streets, finally finding my way home.

The reason why hot water is more effective at dissolving sugar than cold water is due to the way molecules interact with each other.

In a solution, molecules of a substance (in this case, sugar) dissolve in a solvent (water) to form a homogeneous mixture. The ability of a substance to dissolve in water is determined by the strength of the intermolecular forces between the solvent molecules and the solute molecules.
